Michael Reed, how realistic is it for us to believe if, as Ms. Sedhom suggests, that the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation is not funded as it should be, and more companies are going to turn to this corporation to bail them out?
How reasonable is it to believe that you are just going to find workers who are left out in the cold with absolutely nothing?

I think that the trend away from the defined benefit plan to what's called the defined contribution plan is a trend that is going to continue because of the internationalization of the American economy now.
American workers no longer compete for jobs solely against each other.

They now compete for jobs in an international economy, including Indian workers, Chinese workers under systems where the employers can make payments that are much less than what American workers have grown accustomed to, and justifiably so.
But I think we are living--there is a new paradigm in the world.
And I think that one of the consequences of that paradigm is the effect that it is having upon wages and benefits in the United States.
Ms.
Sedhom, I'm told you believe that many businesses are unfairly using Chapter 11 simply to escape from obligations they now feel it impossible to meet and still meet a profit margin.
Yes, that's correct.
For example, when these companies do promise their employees a certain dollar amount per hour worked, for example, they don't necessarily put the money into the defined benefit plan.
They just see how the market is doing, and rely on their competitors' stock and things like that to fund the pension plan, which is not the purpose of the defined benefit plan.
Michael Reed, it seems a number of people are going to suggest that the little guy is, frankly, left out in the cold.

I keep hammering that point because I talk to--being from Detroit and I travel a lot--many of these blue-collar folks, who find no loyalty to the company, who believe that they're just getting the shaft; they see, as in the case of Polaroid, as we discussed in the segment previous, folks walking away with golden parachutes worth millions, and the workers being stuck with a check for less than $50.
Ed, I want to say two things.
First of all, I come from a working class family in South Philly.
I am not unsympathetic to the plight of my brothers and sisters in the working class category.
I want to say two things, though.
First of all, I think that--I don't want the focus to be solely on the bankruptcy system.
I don't disagree that the social covenant, the economic covenant that was made between workers and businesses 30, 40, 50 years ago, has not been honored.
And that's a reality that gets reflected not only in Chapter 11, but throughout the American economy in general.

But the other thing I want to note is there has been a new bankruptcy bill passed, as I'm sure you've heard, and some of the provisions of that bill that are getting the most notoriety are provisions that, quite frankly, are not very friendly to lower-income Americans.
But, interestingly, there are a few provisions of that new bill that are relevant to the discussion that we're having, and I want to mention them.
There is a provision in the new bill that's going to make it a lot harder for former executives and new executives of companies in Chapter 11 to receive huge bonuses.
There's really going to be a cutback on that.

There's also a provision I think that was primarily--possibly prompted by the Polaroid situation that is going to permit the bankruptcy court to go back and reinstate a retirement benefit plan that was terminated within 180 days prior to the bankruptcy filing.
So Congress did hear some of the justified complaints of the working community in the wake of situations such as Polaroid.
